Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: EaSM 2: Stochastic Simulation and Decadal Prediction of Large-Scale Climate
Award.AbstractNarration:
Under this project, large-scale, low-frequency modes (LFMs) will be studied in observations and simulations of state-of-the-art general circulation models (GCMs) of Earth's climate. This project will build on previous NSF- and DOE-funded work on LFMs arising from the ocean's wind-driven and overturning circulations in the Atlantic and Pacific sectors, as well as from their interactions with the atmosphere and tropical climate variability. This project will focus on: (a) improving current understanding of LFMs and interactions between them; (b) developing, revising and testing statistical methods for probabilistic decadal prediction based on these modes; and (c) using these decadal predictions in conjunction with observations and GCM simulations to gain insight into the dynamical causes of climate change and climate variability at decadal and longer time scales. This project will continue the identification of decadal modes in the Atlantic and Pacific, from both observations and the simulations from the two most recent international climate intercomparison modeling projects, using advanced, data-adaptive spectral methods. These methods will include multi-channel singular spectrum analysis (MSSA), as well as harmonic Koopman analysis (HKA), along with stochastic modeling based on empirical model reduction (EMR). The investigators will further apply novel methods for the study of synchronized chaotic oscillators developed at UCLA and UWM, to gain additional understanding of decadal-scale teleconnections within the Pacific and between the Atlantic and the Pacific, as well as their relationships with the El Nino-Southern Oscillation (ENSO). Using the LFMs studied in the first part of the project, the investigators will examine their decadal predictability and assess the skill of retrospective decadal forecasts made with our new empirical forecast models based on EMR, MSSA and HKA. These empirical forecasts will be compared against the initialized climate predictions being made as part of the IPCC's 5th Assessment Report. This comparison will help quantify potential skill due to intrinsic decadal modes and their interactions with ENSO, as well as with climate change. The combination of these activities will lead to advanced stochastic simulation tools for creating benchmark scenarios of future climate, based on a combination of observed data and the most robust and predictable elements of near-term climate change and climate variability, out to about 2050.

The intellectual merit of this project is in developing versatile statistical tools and methodologies for climate prediction and the validation of dynamical climate models. The project will also advance our understanding of global coupling between prominent large-scale low-frequency modes. An expected outcome of the project is improved estimates of reliability of climate projections, by developing and testing novel metrics - associated with coupling and synchronization between multiple LFMs across the globe - for validating climate model predictions.

The project's broader impacts lie in addressing a problem of utmost societal importance, i.e., understanding climate variability and change. The project's investigators are committed to making their stochastic simulations easily available to the climate community. This work will foster scientific partnerships between UCLA and UWM, and further the development of graduate curricula in climate dynamics at both institutions. The principal investigators will broadly disseminate the results by means of a dedicated web site, refereed publications, seminars and presentations at national and international meetings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Climate is extremely complex. Identification, as well as attribution of climate signals may be ambiguous. One way of approaching this problem is by concentrating on a subset of large-scale low-frequency climate modes and to determine their reproducibility by climate models and, eventually, their predictability. The major goal of this project was to develop and apply novel techniques for isolating potentially predictable low-frequency modes (LFM), where "low-frequency," in climatic perspective, refers to interannual-to-decadal and longer time scales.

One of the novel identification techniques developed in this project relies on tracking individual cyclones and anticyclones and reconstructing the resulting synoptic field by approximating these features with idealized vortices. The other main technique looks to emulate the observed climate evolution on all time scales; it is referred to as the Empirical Model Reduction (EMR) technique. Finally, we have applied the tools of information theory to study multi-scale climatic interactions associated, in particular, with LFMs.

The project thus went in three main directions:

  • methodological development of LFM identification via feature tracking and state-of- the-art high-dimensional empirical modeling
  • Identification and analysis of large-scale multidecadal teleconnections operating throughout the Northern Hemisphere in climate models and reanalysis observations
  • Diagnosis and theoretical analysis of multi-scale interactions in the climate system

The key outcomes are as follows:

(1) We developed a novel technique for the analysis of the LFM in observations and model generated data sets based on tracking indiviual synoptic features in the sea-level pressure field.

(2) We gained new theoretical insights into the anatomy of the LFMs when viewed as structures consisting of the cyclone/anticyclone "building blocks" and their variability.

(3) We demonstrated an amazing skill of EMR-based emulators for sea-level pressure (SLP) and vector-wind variability in the Northern Hemisphere. We further improved the high-resolution EMR methodology, which allowed skillful emulation of complex spatiotemporal behavior of precipitation over the domain of Japan's regional reanalysis. The model emulation was used for flood-risk estimation by AIR Worldwide Corporation.

(4) We developed a detailed strategy for constructing truly multi-scale empirical coupled climate EMR models and applied it to multi-scale modeling of surface air temperature over North America. As a result, we produced and published the data set for a 100-member ensemble empirical-model simulation of surface temperature. This library provides a valuable resource for scientific analyses of historical temperature variability (including extremes) and a variety of probabilistic applications.

(5) Using a novel semi-empirical attribution approach, we performed an improved diagnosis of multidecadal climate variability in CMIP5 models and observations, and provided a compelling evidence for the striking departures of CMIP5 models from the observed multidecadal variability. We also verified low-dimensional spatiotemporal structure of these departures dubbed "the stadium wave." We believe that diagnosing the dynamical causes of the stadium wave absence from CMIP5 simulations may potentially be one of the most important near-term tasks of global climate modeling efforts.

(7) We documented striking effects of decadal climate variability on the seasonal cycle and temperature extremes over Europe.

(8) We provided compact description of multi-scale interactions in the observed ENSO and documented systematic failure of state-of-the-art, as well as conceptual climate models to capture these interactions.

The UWM component of this collaborative project resulted in 10 peer-reviewed research papers, one master thesis and numerious conference presentations and seminars. It provided part-time training for four graduate students.

The activities related to this project fostered the existing collaboration between UCLA and UWM, and resulted in developing collaborations between UWM and P. P. Shirshov Institute of Oceanology (Moscow, Russia), as well as between UWM and University of Melbourne (Australia). Another promising collaboration that was initiated in the first year of the project and is still ongoing is between UWM and a private forecasting firm — Air Worldwide Corporation —based in Boston MA. This collaboration is ongoing.

Potential impacts of this project are as follows:

  • A novel empirical-dynamical downscaling schemes being developed within this project may provide a breakthrough in the ways the regional downscaling is done in the context of decadal climate change and forecasting.
  • The connection between the synoptic eddies and low-frequency modes established within our project may contribute in major ways to our theoretical understanding of climate dynamics
  • The high-dimensional empirical climate emulators have numerous applications in climate dowanscaling, prediction and modeling.
  • The identification of ubiquitous and very pronounced multidecadal climate variability of atmospheric teleconnections in observations and lack thereof in current-generation climate models is a major finding which will significantly affect our assessment of the causes of the 20th century climate change and may guide the routes for further model development.
  • The high-dimensional empirical models developed in this project can be utilized in essentially any discipline, and are in this sense "globally" significant.
  • These models have already sparked interest, and will undoubtedly draw further attention in risk-assessment applications, thus demonstrating their great commercialization potential.
